femaleInfertility.overviewText: Female infertility is defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months of unprotected sexual intercourse. It accounts for about 40–50% of infertility cases globally, and Sri Lanka faces similar trends due to lifestyle, medical, and environmental factors.
causes: Ovulation Disorders: Conditions like Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) or hormonal imbalance can disrupt egg release.
Blocked Fallopian Tubes: Often caused by infections or pelvic inflammatory disease.
Endometriosis: Tissue growth outside the uterus affecting implantation.
Uterine Conditions: Fibroids or structural abnormalities that hinder conception.
Age Factor: Fertility declines significantly after 35.
Lifestyle Factors: Stress, smoking, and poor diet can affect reproductive health.
diagnosis: Hormone Level Testing: Evaluates ovulation and ovarian reserve.
Ultrasound Scans: Detects PCOS, fibroids, or endometriosis.
Hysterosalpingography (HSG): X-ray to check if fallopian tubes are open.
Laparoscopy: Minimally invasive surgery to inspect reproductive organs.
treatments: Medication: Fertility drugs like Clomiphene for ovulation induction.
Surgery: For fibroids, endometriosis, or tubal blockages.
Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ART): IVF or ICSI for severe cases.
Intrauterine Insemination (IUI): A less invasive first-line treatment for mild cases.
femaleInfertility.treatmentsNote: These treatments are available at leading clinics like Ninewells Care IVF Centre, Asiri Fertility Centre, and Nawaloka Hospital Fertility Unit.
tips: Maintain a healthy weight and balanced diet.
Manage stress with yoga or meditation.
Avoid smoking, alcohol, and excessive caffeine.
Track ovulation cycles for better timing.
Consult a doctor early if you face irregular cycles or symptoms of PCOS.
resources: Sri Lanka College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
femaleInfertility.bottomLineText: Female infertility is treatable with timely intervention, lifestyle changes, and medical support. Early consultation improves success rates.

maleInfertility.heroDescription: Understand the causes, treatments, and resources for male infertility in Sri Lanka.
maleInfertility.overviewText: Male infertility refers to a man's inability to cause pregnancy in a fertile female partner. It accounts for nearly 40-50% of all infertility cases worldwide. In Sri Lanka, lifestyle changes, environmental factors, and untreated medical conditions have made male infertility an increasing concern.
maleInfertility.definitionText: Infertility in men usually occurs due to low sperm production, abnormal sperm function, or blockages that prevent sperm delivery. Other factors include hormonal imbalances and chronic health issues.
causes: Low Sperm Count (Oligospermia): Most common in Sri Lanka, linked to smoking and poor diet.
Varicocele: Enlarged veins affecting sperm production.
Hormonal Imbalance: Low testosterone or other hormone disorders.
Infections: STDs, mumps, or urinary infections damaging sperm health.
Lifestyle Factors: Stress, obesity, heat exposure, tight clothing.
Genetic Disorders: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome.
maleInfertility.diagnosisIntro: Tests available in Sri Lanka include:
diagnosisTests: Semen Analysis – checks sperm count and motility.
maleInfertility.diagnosisHospitals: Available at hospitals like: Ninewells Hospital, Asiri Medical Hospital, Nawaloka Hospital.
treatments: Lifestyle Changes: Quit smoking, reduce alcohol, healthy weight.
ART: IUI, IVF, or ICSI – most common for severe male infertility.
tips: Avoid prolonged laptop use on laps.
Reduce stress with yoga or meditation.
Exercise regularly, avoid excessive heat exposure.
maleInfertility.whoChartDesc: This interactive chart shows the WHO lower reference values (5th percentile) for key semen parameters across editions, with our 2020 fertile cohort for context. It’s an educational trend, not a diagnosis.
maleInfertility.whoChartSource: Sources: WHO Laboratory Manual for the Examination and Processing of Human Semen, 5th ed (2010) and 6th ed (2021). Reference limits are one-sided at the 5th percentile.

resources.label: Sri Lanka College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists

maleInfertility.bottomLineText: Male infertility is treatable in most cases with proper medical care and lifestyle changes. Early diagnosis improves success rates significantly.
